Eligible to Vote Here
By DON LASSUS
College students in Maryland
are now eligible to vote in their
college communities following a
ruling by the Maryland Attorney
General.
The decision handed down by
Francis B. Burch stated that
students could not be excluded
from the voting register because
they are temporary residents.
No Plans
Although local registrars may
decide whether or not individual
students qualify as residents, a
student may qualify by living in
a dormitory and need not be a
permanent resident, or plan to
reside here following graduation.
According to Burch, students
are considered residents if they
list their college address on
income tax forms, if their
automobiles are registered in
Maryland or if their driver's
license lists a dormitory as
residence.
Other evidence includes local
bank accounts and credit cards,
where most of a student's
personal belongings are, and
whether or not a student is
registered in another state.
Student Power
The decision is expected to
upset the political balance in

such communities as College
Park, Md. where more than
8,000 students at the University
of Maryland will qualify as
residents of the suburban D.C.
community. At present there are
only 3,300 regestered voters in
that community.
The voting strength of U. of
M. students will be tested in
November's election when the
city's mayor and city council are
up for reelection. Thus far,
however, few students have
turned out to take advantage of
the ruling.
Equal Rights
Burch cited the fact that
Maryland would be violating the
students' right to vote under the
new 26th amendment and would
be denying them equal
protection of the laws under the
1 4th amendment which
prohibits discrimination against
persons eligible to vote.
The State Attorney General
also referred to the Supreme
Court decision stating that a
jurisdiction may not "fence out"
a bloc of voters simply because

By RICHARD BLAND
After thirty years of teaching
at Hopkins, Don C. Allen,
English, is in the midst of his last
undergraduate class,
Shakespeare. Next semester he
will continue with a graduate
seminar but otherwise will no
longer teach in class.
Mr. Allen is already three
Years over retirement age, but
• has still sparkled wittily in
English classes here. His special
field . is .16th and 17th century
lite:r.ature and his favorite
courses have been Shakespeare
and Milton.
Wizardly Gentleman
Hearing Dr. Allen in a
Shakespeare class is to hear a
perky stream of detatched and
humorous insights. With it all

comes an intuitive sense of the
plays: their characters, spirit and
looming behind the lectern, the
wizardly white-haired old
gentleman who larkishly keeps
people chuckling.
It all began back at the
University of Illinois where Dr.
Allen started his sophomore year
in 1932 with the intention of
majoring in Bacteriology, a sort
of ancient form of modern
biology. He enrolled in an
English class devised for science
majors, and thanks to the
teacher, Bruce Weirick, he soon
found himself majoring in
English literature. "If it hadn't
been for Mr. Weirick," Allen
says, "I'd probably be working
as a chemist in some cheese
factory now."

Co-eds Unable to Get

At Illinois, Don Allen was also
editor-in -chief of the Daily
Illinois. "Those were the
sporting page days," he says.
"There was little interest in
politics, economics or the
in tellectual world. Everything
was simple minded compared to
now. Kids had an eagerness for
security and a good safe job."
Beer was King
That's changed now and Dr.
Allen is happy. "Students don't
accept things blindly as they
used to, and that's how progress
is made. Leading thinkers always
start by doubting what is being
said."
. Campus life at ,Illinois was
pretty different too. "Girls had
to be in at 10:00 and publishing
satire on Urbana could get you
in hot water in nothing flat. Beer
was the end; the modern
undergrad doesn't realize what
those days were like."
At Hopkins, Don Allen has
been very happy. He particularly
enjoys the academic freedom of
reading and saying what he
pleases in class.
Before coming to Hopkins in
1941, Allen had taught at Purd-

ue, Washington State, Illinois,

Northwestern and Duke. "This is
the freest school I've been at,"
he says, "The administration has
never interfered in any way with
my work. At other places a rich
trustee or alumni would call me
up and wonder why their kid
wasn't a brilliant English
student. Then they'd pressure
the administration. Nothing like
that, has ever happened here.
Professors have been
traditionally judged on one

thing, their performance."
Allen also appreciates students
at Hopkins and is
relieved that education here has
outgrown the system of
"returning vomit to the dog"
that characterized many of his
earlier teaching jobs.
He remembers his early years
at Hopkins when there were just
four people in the English
department, three in History and
four in Romance languages.
"Nine people came to a baseball
game once," he said, referring to
the Hopkins team. "There were
just six buildings. Merganthaler
was just finished and the library
was in Gilman."
Allen considers the Hopkins
English department as one of the
best in the country. "With our
eight or nine people, the
national appraisal still puts us
eighth in the country. That's
higher than any other
department here at Hopkins,
except maybe Biology."
D. C. Allen can't think of
another school in the U.S. that
he would have been happier at
than Hopkins. "I even wish I'd
been an undergraduate here."

By HOWARD WEAVER
The Hopkins Club is housed
in an inconspicuous two-story
building just north-east of the
President's house. Since 1937
the club has catered to faculty
members, providing a relaxed
and inexpensive dining facility,
removed from the daily activity
of the campus.
"The Hopkins Club provides
the faculty with a place to get
away from the cares and problems of their school day," said
Club manager Richard A. Cartwright. The Club, screened from
the campus by shrubs and trees,
is cool and quiet, with simple,
elegant furnishings.
Student Breakfast
A newly-approved program allows students to eat breakfast at
the Club, after paying a $10.00
annual fee. Patrons are billed
monthly., no cash is accepted at
the Club.
The main entrance to the
Club, which now serves Hopkins
alumni and some administrators,
opens on a foyer complete with
alabaster statues and Persian
rugs, ending in a spiral stairway
leading to the pool tables and
game rooms on the second level.
Meals at the Club are an uncommon combination of good
food, pleasant atmosphere and
low prices. Servants, primarily
middle-aged black women, move
with quiet grace through the dining rooms, serving the diners'
choice of two or three entrees
from the daily-varied menu.
Inexpensive
Prices range from $1.00 for
lunch (sample menu: Sauteed
Chicken Livers, Broiled Fish or
Cold Turkey with two vegetables
and choice of soups and deserts)

to a $3.00 charge for dinner.
Cartwright reports that luncheon
is served to a clientele of 95 per
cent faculty, while the dinner
service finds about 90 per cent
alumni in attendance.
The meals are prepared by a
staff which has been with the
club for years; the newest addi-

tion to the cooking staff came to
the club eight years ago. No convenience foods are used, and the
staff prepares its own soups
The club operates continually
at near maximum capacity. "We
never have a vacant seat at
lunch, Monday through Friday,"
Cartwright said.

Freshman Primaries
Slated for This Week
Low interest has marred the
upcoming primaries for
freshman class offices on Sept.
30 and Oct. 1. Except for the
Presidency, few of the other
posts--Vice-President,
Secretary, Treasurer or
Representative--have attracted
much attention. Only 13
aspirants have turned in
petitions.
The primary election will be
held in the Gilman bookstore
from 11:30 p.m. to 1:00 p.m.
and in the dorm cafeteria from
5:00 p.m. to 6:30 p.m. If there
are ally deadlocks, a run-off
election will be held at the same
times on Oct. 4.
Class elections in recent years
have tended to produce a weak
response.
The election is being run by
senior Bob Belflower. "This
year's class is the straightest in
years," he noted.
Federalist Candidate
The campaign is highlighted
by Walter Lorenzo's candidacy
for Treasurer. A self-styled
Federalist, Lorenzo remarked,"I
want to impose order on tile

Student Council." He added,
"Individual thought is conducive
to mayhem and disorder." He
also said that he distrusted the
news media.
Candidates for President are
Emmet Finucane, John McClure,
Charles Gilman, Andrew Savitz
and Dean Gain. Finucane has
run the largest campaign, with
more posters than the other
candidates. He said, "I advocate
the construction of a freshman
coffee house, the improvement
of the food and the abolition of
rules requiring freshman to live
in the dorms."
The two candidates for
Vice-President are Udo Wahn
and Paul Stein.
As of Sunday night, there
were no candidates for
Secretary. Belflower stated that
the post will be awarded to any
student with a majority of
write-in votes.

An eager audience filed into the Morris
Mechanic Theater last Wednesday night to see
the opening of "No Place to be Somebody."
Many of them were black, most of them were
young, and there was a large sampling of the
little-seen upper class echelons of Baltimore
black society.
A feeling of being predisposed to enjoy the
play floated through the chic and modern theater
as as the audience awaited the curtain's rise, and
when it finally did, we were all impressed with
the convincing and detailed stage setting, a West
Greenwich village bar
named "Johnny's" with
three tables, the bar,
and a jukebox.
A bar is a convenient
and often-used device
for a play, as it allows
credible transitions for
the for the actors and is popularly conceived of
as a good place in which to pour out troubles; it
fits, because this play deals with black-white
relationships as confused by human aspirations;
both blacks and whites seeing salvation in the
life-styles of the other race.
Gabe Gabriel, played by Chuck Daniel, is a
black actor who is trying to stop being black;in a
series of monologues preceding each act, he rants
about how much he has washed and washed,
trying to become white, to no avail.
On the other hand is Dee, played by Elaine
Kilden; she has the misfortune of being a
prostitute in love with her pimp, Johnny, bar
owner and aspiring racketeer. In the last act,
when she finds her love unrequited, she smears
black paint on her face in a pitiful but useless
attempt to change things.
Shanty (Jack Shanahan) is the bar's nigger,
though he is white. He carries a set of drumsticks
through his belt loops and once sat in with Max

Roach. However, when the genuine and simple
black woman (Shezwae Powell) he is to marry
finally scrapes up enough money to buy him a
set of "skins', he sits down to a pathetic
rythin-less banging, which frustrates him into
violently shaking his girlfriend by the neck and
telling her that they are through. He, too, is
unable to live up to his racial aspiration.
Charles Gordone, the author/director of
"No Place to be Somebody," won a Pulitzer
Prize for this play, perhaps because it
incorporates some of the most genuine and
prevalent black-white sentiments in parts of
today's society; the
dialogue is often
riotously funny, and
rings very true.

glossary, including such

The whole play is a trifle too long, with two

hours, including the intermissions.

shows were not the main
attraction at this fair.

putting on displays, and trying
to have all of the fun that a half
million people can have.

weekend was just not enough
time to allow everyone to fully
enjoy the wide assortment of
distractions put on displays.

slippers.

booth filled their hands with

The scale is vastly different, and
Sickler considers the size of the
Levering project "not exciting."
Its other aspects, however, make
it the favorite project around his
office, which is young both in
terms of its ideas and the people
who staff it.
Sickler considers interior
work an integral part of design,
and would not turn it over to a
"decorator." He likes the
concept of having no wall,
visually, between the person
inside and the outdoors. This is
apt for Levering, because of the
beautiful view of Wyman Park;
the little ravine, the bridge, and
the woods beyond.
The prognosis on the time
required for the project is
simple: "Quickly." Sickler
intends to work with visual
models, which can easily be
changed and which are the best
explanatory language of
architecture.
